ThingDef.label: cannibal pemmican
ThingDef.description: A preserved mashed mixture of human fat and plant food. Tastes bland, but not offensive. It lasts a very long time without refrigeration.

ThingDef.label: cannibal kibble
ThingDef.description: Animal feed made from human and plant sources. Humans can eat it, but they really, really don't like it.

ThingDef.label: cannibal packaged survival meal
ThingDef.description: A high-quality cannibal packaged meal, manufactured for use in survival situations.

ThingDef.label: cannibal simple meal
ThingDef.description: A simple meal quickly cooked from human meat and a few ingredients.

ThingDef.label: cannibal fine meal
ThingDef.description: A complex dish assembled with care from human meat and a wide selection of ingredients.

ThingDef.label: cannibal lavish meal
ThingDef.description: A masterpiece of the cannibal culinary arts, this meal nourishes the body, mind, and soul.

ThingDef.label: insect pemmican
ThingDef.description: A preserved mashed mixture of insect fat and plant food. Tastes bland, but not offensive. It lasts a very long time without refrigeration.

ThingDef.label: insect kibble
ThingDef.description: Animal feed made from insect and plant sources. Humans can eat it, but they really, really don't like it.

ThingDef.label: insect packaged survival meal
ThingDef.description: A high-quality insect packaged meal, manufactured for use in survival situations.

ThingDef.label: insect simple meal
ThingDef.description: A simple meal quickly cooked from insect meat and a few ingredients.

ThingDef.label: insect fine meal
ThingDef.description: A complex dish assembled with care from insect meat and a wide selection of ingredients.

ThingDef.label: insect lavish meal
ThingDef.description: A masterpiece of the insect culinary arts, this meal nourishes the body, mind, and soul.

ThingDef.label: borscht
ThingDef.description: An Eastern European sour soup made with red beetroot and meat stock, originating from Ukraine on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: Caesar salad
ThingDef.description: A simple tossed salad consisting of romaine lettuce, croutons and dressing. Despite its name, Caesar salad actually originates from Baja California in Mexico on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: Cuban sandwich
ThingDef.description: A variant of the classic ham and cheese sandwich introduced by Cuban immigrants to Miami and Tampa on Old Earth at the turn of the 20th Century. Made with long Cuban bread and cut diagonally before serving.

ThingDef.label: currywurst
ThingDef.description: Steamed and fried pork sausages sliced into bite-sized pieces and covered with curry ketchup, popularized as fast food in Germany on Old Earth in the late 1940s. Served with thick-cut fries.

ThingDef.label: dumplings
ThingDef.description: Ground meat and vegetables wrapped with thinly-rolled wheat dough into small parcels, and cooked by boiling. Commonly eaten as a entrée or light meal in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Administrative Region Four on Old Earth since antiquity.

ThingDef.label: fish n' chips
ThingDef.description: Fried fish in batter served with chips (thick-cut fries), a popular takeaway food in Commonwealth and other English-speaking nations on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: gyros
ThingDef.description: Meat cooked on a vertical rotisserie and wrapped with tomatoes and onion in pita bread, popular in Greece on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: kakigori
ThingDef.description: An Old Earth Japanese shaved ice dessert topped with various syrups and sweeteners, hugely popular in summer.

ThingDef.label: Margherita pizza
ThingDef.description: Slices of rustic pizza topped with crushed tomatoes, mozzarella cheese and sprigs of basil, originating from Italy on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: minced pork rice
ThingDef.description: A bowl of rice topped with braised ground pork and a slice of pickled vegetable, originating from Taiwan on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: pancakes
ThingDef.description: A generous stack of buttermilk pancakes drizzled with maple syrup from Old Earth Canada.

ThingDef.label: pastrami on rye
ThingDef.description: A sandwich consisting of sliced pastrami (cured and smoked beef brisket) served on rye bread, popularized by Jewish immigrants to New York on Old Earth in the late 1800s.

ThingDef.label: pork buns
ThingDef.description: Ground pork wrapped in yeast-leavened dough before steaming, commonly eaten as a snack in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan and Administrative Region Four on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: poutine
ThingDef.description: A greasy dish of french fries and cheese curds topped with brown gravy, originating from the Quebec region of Canada on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: sachertorte
ThingDef.description: A decadent slice of chocolate sponge cake with apricot jam filling and dark chocolate icing, replicated under licence from the successors of the Hotel Sacher in Austria on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: shrimp tacos
ThingDef.description: Small hand-sized corn tortillas filled with fried shrimp, lettuce and avocado salsa, originating from Baja California in Mexico on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: takoyaki
ThingDef.description: A popular snack in Japan on Old Earth, made by cooking diced octopus meat into thick, battered balls. Served topped with Worcester sauce, mayonnaise, green laver and dried bonito shavings.

ThingDef.label: tiramisu
ThingDef.description: A layered dessert of coffee-soaked sponge cake biscuits, cream and cheese, hailing from Italy on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: Weisswurst
ThingDef.description: A traditional Old Earth Bavarian sausage, made from minced veal and pork back bacon. Typically served with sweet mustard and soft pretzels.

ThingDef.label: zongzi
ThingDef.description: Parcels of glutinous rice, meat and other savory fillings wrapped in bamboo leaves before steaming or boiling. Commonly eaten as a light meal in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore and Administrative Region Four on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: beef noodle soup
ThingDef.description: Braised beef, vegetables and noodles served in a beef broth, commonly served at street stalls in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Administrative Region Four on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: beef rouladen
ThingDef.description: A traditional Old Earth German dish consisting of thin, tenderized beef steaks rolled with a filling of bacon, mustard and pickles, before being simmered in a rich gravy. Served with braised red cabbage and potato dumplings.

ThingDef.label: bunny chow
ThingDef.description: A hollowed-out loaf of white bread filled with lamb curry, popularized by Indian immigrants to South Africa on Old Earth in the 1940s. Served with a salad.

ThingDef.label: chaliapin steak
ThingDef.description: A beef steak tenderized with onions, served with watercress and sauteed potatoes. Originally invented in Japan on Old Earth in the mid-1930s, to cater for a Russian opera singer suffering from a toothache.

ThingDef.label: chicken and waffles
ThingDef.description: Fried chicken served on waffles, a Pennsylvanian Dutch dish popularized in the Southern United States on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: chicken Kyiv
ThingDef.description: Breaded chicken cutlets stuffed with butter and herbs, popular in Russia, Ukraine and other former Eastern Bloc states on Old Earth. Served with mashed potatoes.

ThingDef.label: chicken pot pie
ThingDef.description: A meat pie with a flaky pastry crust paired with a creamy chicken and mushroom filling, originating from Britain on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: chicken tikka masala
ThingDef.description: Chunks of chicken marinated in spices and yoghurt, roasted and served in a creamy, spiced tomato-based sauce, popularized by Indian immigrants to Britain on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: jollof rice
ThingDef.description: An aromatic one-pot rice and tomato stew dish popular throughout West Africa on Old Earth, often paired with various vegetables and meat.

ThingDef.label: käsespätzle
ThingDef.description: European egg noodles layered with cheese and baked like a casserole, traditionally served in Germany and Austria on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: katsu curry
ThingDef.description: A breaded and fried pork cutlet served with rice and curry, popular in Japan on Old Earth. Served with a refreshing shredded cabbage salad.

ThingDef.label: koshari
ThingDef.description: A mixed rice, pasta and lentil vegetarian dish popular as street food in Egypt on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: loco moco
ThingDef.description: A generous portion of white rice topped with a hamburger patty, a sunny-side up fried egg and brown gravy, originating from Hawaii on Old Earth in the late 1940s.

ThingDef.label: nachos
ThingDef.description: An Old Earth Tex-Mex dish, consisting of tortilla chips covered with refried beans, ground meat, shredded cheese and hot sauce.

ThingDef.label: omurice
ThingDef.description: Chicken fried rice covered with a thin egg omelette, popular in Japan on Old Earth. Often topped with motivational messages written in ketchup.

ThingDef.label: paella
ThingDef.description: A rice dish originating from Valencia, Spain on Old Earth, cooked in saffron and chicken broth over a shallow pan, and topped with various meats, seafoods and vegetables.

ThingDef.label: phở
ThingDef.description: Rice noodles, meat and vegetables served in clear broth, originating from Old Earth Vietnam.

ThingDef.label: ramen
ThingDef.description: A highly-popular Japanese dish of Old Earth East Asian origins, consisting of wheat noodles served in pork bone broth with a variety of toppings.

ThingDef.label: ratatouille
ThingDef.description: A traditional vegetable stew originating from France on Old Earth, artistically arranged in confit byaldi form.

ThingDef.label: shepherd's pie
ThingDef.description: A minced meat pie topped with mash potato, originating from Britain and France on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: tagliatelle al ragù
ThingDef.description: Flat ribbon pasta generously topped with a slow-cooked meat sauce. The dish is widely-regarded the authentic traditional Old Earth Italian version of the genericized spaghetti bolognese.

ThingDef.label: tenzaru soba
ThingDef.description: Chilled buckwheat noodles served on a bamboo tray, accompanied by dipping sauce and a mound of tempura vegetables and seafood. Commonly eaten during summer in Japan on Old Earth.

ThingDef.label: full English breakfast
ThingDef.description: A hearty cooked breakfast dish popular in the British Isles on Old Earth, consisting of bacon, sausages, eggs, mushrooms, tomatoes, toast and baked beans.

ThingDef.label: gumbo
ThingDef.description: A hearty Creole stew of meat, shellfish and vegetables thickened with okra, representing a fusion of Old Earth African, French, Spanish and Native American cuisine. Served with a generous portion of rice.

ThingDef.label: Hāngī
ThingDef.description: An Old Earth New Zealand Maori feast of meats and root vegetables, traditionally cooked buried in earthen pits heated by hot stones.

ThingDef.label: kaiseki
ThingDef.description: A traditional Old Earth Japanese multi-course feast of carefully-curated and artistically-arranged seasonal ingredients.

ThingDef.label: Lobster Thermidor
ThingDef.description: A classic Old Earth French dish, consisting of lobster meat cooked in a rich wine-and-cheese sauce, stuffed back into its shell and browned to perfection. Served with steamed green beans and roast potatoes.

ThingDef.label: Sunday roast
ThingDef.description: A traditional Old Earth British feast of roasted meat, potatoes and other vegetables, accompanied by Yorkshire pudding with gravy.

ThingDef.label: black tea
ThingDef.description: A particularly bitter tea cut with creamy milk, wakes one up and helps cure ailments.

ThingDef.label: cannibal coffee
ThingDef.description: For a very particular… refined coffee drinker.

ThingDef.label: irish coffee
ThingDef.description: Whiskey and coffee blended thoroughly before forming a head and being topped with a spoonful of whipped cream. Perfect for those who just got out of bed and are already wanting to go back to it.

ThingDef.label: kombucha tea
ThingDef.description: A sugary tea left out to ferment, after fermenting the end product is a sweet and sour, sometimes even naturally fizzy drink known as kombucha. Praised for health benefits, though some remain skeptical. Kombucha acts as a home remedy against the flu, reducing its severity by 5%.

ThingDef.label: latte coffee
ThingDef.description: Potent espresso mixed with fresh milk to help ease bitterness before pouring and serving. Lattes have a reputation of being particularly meant for “sophisticated” individuals.

ThingDef.label: mocha coffee
ThingDef.description: Coffee mixed with sweet and luxurious chocolate, very fun to drink. Those of snobbish persuasion would argue mocha is more of a dessert than an actual coffee drink.

ThingDef.label: pumpkin spice coffee
ThingDef.description: Cheap, mass produced generic coffee seeped in an array of spices, oddly excluding any actual pumpkin. Thousands of years ago, this type of coffee was stereotypically consumed by red-haired hipsters with man buns.

ThingDef.label: yuenyeung
ThingDef.description: A mixture of coffee and tea. Tea and coffee drinkers respectively set their differences aside while concocting this unholy amalgamation. It is usually served cold, but whether it’s served hot or cold it’s equally confusing to the imbiber.

ThingDef.label: dalgona coffee
ThingDef.description: A trendy, newer drink in the world of coffee rumored to originate from far off steamworlds. Coffee granules are rapidly mixed with sugar to form a thick, luxuriously sweet foam. Afterwards the foam is dispersed over deeply chilled milk before drinking. Arguably the perfect drink to sip on while studying or reading.

ThingDef.label: green tea
ThingDef.description: A light, citrusy green tea spiked with sugar to create a buttery, almost nutty flavor.

ThingDef.label: masala chai
ThingDef.description: A musty, warm, almost woody tea crafted by simple leaves and complex spices. Masala chai acts as a home remedy against wound infections, reducing the severity of a random infection by 5%.

ThingDef.label: mint coffee
ThingDef.description: Bitter espresso mixed with cream or milk, then further mixed with mint oil and garnished. Cool and velvety coffee gives way to an even cooler, soothing aftertaste, not to mention great smelling breath.

ThingDef.label: mint tea
ThingDef.description: Black tea leaves mixed with mint leaves and deeply steeped, then garnished with additional mint leaves. Leaves your breath surprisingly fresh.

ThingDef.label: noon chai
ThingDef.description: An ancient Kashmiri tea mixing tea leaves, a pinch of salt and baking soda, which results in an striking pink beverage that is famous for being not only delicious but also healthy for the body. Used for treating muscle parasites.

ThingDef.label: mint leaves
ThingDef.description: Mint leaves are infamous for their cooling effect on one's mouth, as well as ease of seeping into an array of teas or delicately garnishing a dish. Mint leaves rot quite fast.

ThingDef.label: earl grey tea
ThingDef.description: A very strong and semi-sweet fruity tea. Floral notes dance around one's pallet at even the most dull scent. People who finish the drink feel strangely urged to colonize.

ThingDef.label: espresso romano
ThingDef.description: A particularly strange combination. Already acidic coffee garnished with a wedge of more acidic lemon, meant to be juiced into the coffee before quickly consumed while hot. An acquired taste to be sure but lauded by those who do prefer it. Specially indicated to combat intestinal parasites.

ThingDef.label: lemonade
ThingDef.description: A sweet beverage mixed together with lemon juice, sugar, and water.

ThingDef.label: lemon tea
ThingDef.description: A dark tea cut with water, chilled and garnished with a wedge of bright lemon.

ThingDef.label: lemons
ThingDef.description: An acid and sour tasting fruit. The juice, zest, and pulp are often used in cooking, often on fish and other meat for better taste. Lemon is also used to flavour drinks, such as lemonade, or mixed with tea and coffee.

ThingDef.label: uncooked simple stew
ThingDef.description: An uncooked simple stew. This needs to be cooked in a stew pot to be edible.

ThingDef.label: simple stew
ThingDef.description: A simple stew slow cooked from a few ingredients.

ThingDef.label: uncooked fine stew
ThingDef.description: An uncooked fine stew. This needs to be cooked in a stew pot to be edible.

ThingDef.label: fine stew
ThingDef.description: A complex stew assembled with care from a wide selection of ingredients.

ThingDef.label: uncooked lavish stew
ThingDef.description: An uncooked lavish stew. This needs to be cooked in a stew pot to be edible.

ThingDef.label: lavish stew
ThingDef.description: A masterpiece of the culinary arts, this stew nourishes the body, mind, and soul.

ThingDef.label: muff beer
ThingDef.description: The one and only Muff Beer brand, contains sweet herbal remedies for an added flavour. The first beverage besides water ever consumed by mankind. Beer can taste good, but its main effect is intoxication. Excessive consumption can lead to alcohol blackouts and, over time, addiction.

ThingDef.label: randy burger
ThingDef.description: A semi-complex dish assembled with care from a variety of ingredients.

ThingDef.label: ZZT! Cola
ThingDef.description: A non-alcoholic soft drink. Cola is a sweetened, carbonated soft drink flavored with natural flavorings. This brand of Soda is of the ZZT! Cola brand, tastes like an Orange and Mango fizzy drink.

ThingDef.label: German military EPA
ThingDef.description: Regular dry rations of the Bundeswehr military personnel, EPU (Einmannpackung). A securely packaged daily ration including a variety of dishes and snacks that are distributed on a menu of 3 types. It is famous for the quality of its products and taste criteria. Ideal for long journeys or operations. It is considered one of the best military individual rations of NATO.

ThingDef.label: Vegetarian German EPA
ThingDef.description: Vegetarian version of the Bundeswehr EPA ration. Contains only plant-based food components.

ThingDef.label: Meat-only German EPA
ThingDef.description: High-protein version of German EPA ration focused solely on meat and animal-based products.

ThingDef.label: JSDF military ration pack
ThingDef.description: Individual military ration of JSDF (Japanese Self Defense Forces). High-quality military meal pack designed to provide essential nutrition and energy to soldiers in the field. This ration pack includes a variety of delicious and culturally appropriate dishes, ensuring that troops stay well-fed and morale remains high during extended missions.

ThingDef.label: Vegetarian JSDF ration
ThingDef.description: Vegetarian version of JSDF ration. Contains only plant-based components, ideal for dietary or religious restrictions.

ThingDef.label: Meat-only JSDF ration
ThingDef.description: Meat-rich variant of JSDF ration pack. Focuses on protein from meat and animal products only.

ThingDef.label: Russian military IRP
ThingDef.description: IRP of the Army of the Russian Federation (Individual Ration Pack). A securely packaged individual soldier's ration. It has a variety of dishes and snacks on the menu, focusing on meat and grains. It is famous for its meat pate and multifunctional biscuits.

ThingDef.label: Vegetarian Russian IRP
ThingDef.description: Plant-based version of the Russian military IRP. No meat, only grains, vegetables, and snacks.

ThingDef.label: Meat-only Russian IRP
ThingDef.description: High-protein meat-focused variation of the Russian IRP. Contains only animal products.

ThingDef.label: Turkish "Ta!Da!" MRE
ThingDef.description: Turkish civilian individual ration (Ta!Da!). Designed for use in long-term outdoor activity. It contains 3 ready-to-eat dishes and a variety of snacks and drinks. It is nutritious, practical and convenient

ThingDef.label: Vegetarian Turkish MRE
ThingDef.description: Vegetarian version of the Turkish "Ta!Da!" MRE. 100% plant-based rations suitable for long operations.

ThingDef.label: Meat-only Turkish MRE
ThingDef.description: High-protein meat-focused version of Turkish "Ta!Da!" field ration. Contains no plant ingredients.

ThingDef.label: US Military MRE
ThingDef.description: A US military Meal, Ready-to-Eat. Professionally prepared and packaged in portions, individual food ration. Tasty and nutritious, ideal for long field operations or survival in harsh environment. It is also an excellent alternative to crayons

ThingDef.label: US Vegetarian MRE
ThingDef.description: The vegetarian version of the American IRP. Contains only herbal ingredients. Suitable for special dietary and religious restrictions.

ThingDef.label: US Meat-only MRE
ThingDef.description: The high-protein meat diet of the USA. It contains only meat and animal products. Designed for fighters who prefer a hearty diet.я
